answers.explanation: As of March 31, 2025, a total of 1,194 companies have been successfully resolved under the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC) framework, enabling creditors to realize an amount of ₹3.89 lakh crore.

The CAA Rules were amended on 4th September, 2025, to include additional classes for fast-track merger. One of these new classes is 'Two or more unlisted companies (other than section 8 companies) which meet prescribed thresholds of outstanding loans, debentures or deposits'.

The current affairs content for March 2025 specifically mentions two distinct events: India signing a Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement with the European Union, and the expansion of the BRICS group to include new members like Saudi Arabia and the UAE.

As per sub-section (11) of Section 2 of the Finance Bill, the amount of income-tax and surcharge shall be further increased by an additional surcharge called the 'Health and Education Cess on income-tax', calculated at the rate of four per cent. (Page 31)
The Government of India launched the National Quantum Mission in September 2025 with a total financial allocation of ₹6,000 crore to be implemented over a period of 5 years.

In the case of every firm or local authority with a total income exceeding one crore rupees, the income tax shall be increased by a surcharge calculated at the rate of twelve per cent. (Page 13, 85, 86)
The current affairs content for May 2025 states that India became the world's 3rd largest economy with a GDP of $4.5 trillion, surpassing Japan.

The substituted Section 149(1)(b) allows for a notice to be issued if three years and three months, but not more than five years and three months, have elapsed from the end of the relevant assessment year, provided the Assessing Officer has evidence that the income chargeable to tax which has escaped assessment amounts to or is likely to amount to fifty lakh rupees or more. (Page 56)

Clause 19 amends Section 80LA(2)(d) by extending the deadline for commencement of operation for a unit in an IFSC leasing aircraft or ships from 31st March 2025 to 31st March 2030. (Page 43, Page 149)

Clause 17 inserts a new proviso in section 80CCD(1B) to allow a deduction for payment or deposit made to the account of a minor under the pension scheme, subject to a maximum aggregate amount of fifty thousand rupees. (Page 42, Page 148)
The unemployment rate for individuals aged 15 years and above has steadily declined from 6 per cent in 2017-18 to 3.2 per cent in 2023-24, as per the 2023-24 annual PLFS report. (Page 76)

The analysis shows a sharp decline in multidimensional poverty, with an estimated 13.5 crore Indians escaping it between 2015-16 and 2019-21, putting India on track to achieve SDG Target 1.2 well ahead of 2030. (Page 265)
The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) unanimously voted to keep the policy repo rate under the liquidity adjustment facility (LAF) unchanged at 5.50 per cent.
The amendment to Section 115BAC specifies a tax rate of 5 per cent for total income ranging from Rs. 4,00,001 to Rs. 8,00,000, effective from the assessment year 2026-27. (Page 46)

Atul Bheda was appointed as the Chairman of SEBI in February 2025. Sanjay Malhotra's appointment was in Dec 2024 (though he took charge in Jan 2025, the appointment was earlier). CS Setty's appointment was in Sep 2025, Madhabi Puri Buch's reappointment was in May 2025, and Dinesh Khara's reappointment was in Nov 2024. Therefore, only Atul Bheda's appointment falls within the Q1 2025 timeframe.

Macro stress tests indicate that if the macroeconomic environment worsens to a severe stress scenario, the GNPA ratio for all SCBs may rise from 3.2 per cent to 4.4 per cent by September 2024. (Page 91)

The Government of India plans to borrow ₹6.77 lakh crore in the second half of the fiscal year 2025-26 (H2: FY 2025-26) through dated securities, which includes ₹10,000 crore through the issuance of Sovereign Green Bonds (SGrBs).
Clause 24 amends Section 115BAC, introducing a new tax table. For the income slab from Rs. 8,00,001 to Rs. 12,00,000, the applicable rate of tax is 10 per cent. (Page 46)

The Government of India and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) signed a $125 million loan agreement to enhance urban livability and bolster climate resilience in six district headquarters and Guwahati, in the State of Assam.
The MPC decided to reduce the policy repo rate by 25 basis points from 6.50 per cent to 6.25 per cent in the February 2025 meeting. (Page 112, 115)

Taking into account the rise in agricultural input costs and overall inflation since the last revision in 2019, it has been decided to increase the limit for collateral-free agriculture loans from ₹1.6 lakh to ₹2 lakh per borrower. (Page 13, 22)
To encourage wider adoption of UPI, it was decided to increase the UPI Lite wallet limit from ₹2,000 to ₹5,000 and the per-transaction limit from ₹500 to ₹1,000. (Pages 14, 22)

Analysis reveals that the compounded quarterly growth rate (CQGR) of deseasonalised quarterly GDP was greater in the period Q3 FY21 – Q4 FY24 at 1.9% than the CQGR of 1.5% in the pre-pandemic period of Q1 FY12 – Q4 FY20. (Table I.1, page 63)
Clause 63 amends section 194LBC to substitute the varying rates of 25% or 30% with a uniform TDS rate of ten per cent. (Page 57, Page 168)

The MPC unanimously voted to reduce the policy repo rate by 25 basis points from 6.50 per cent to 6.25 per cent in its February 2025 meeting. This was the first rate reduction since February 2023. (Page 89, 112, 115)

In the tightening cycle from May 2022 to March 2024, the WADTDR on outstanding term deposits increased by 185 basis points. During the same period, the policy repo rate was increased by 250 bps. (Page 115, Table III.4)
Real GDP growth for Q3:2023-24 was placed at 8.4 per cent, underpinned by strong investment and an improvement in private consumption. (Page 11)

During the May 2022 to December 2024 period, Public Sector Banks (PSBs) showed a higher transmission of the policy rate hike. The Weighted Average Domestic Term Deposit Rate (WADTDR) on fresh deposits increased by 274 bps for PSBs compared to 214 bps for Private Sector Banks (PVBs). Similarly, the Weighted Average Lending Rate (WALR) on fresh rupee loans increased by 177 bps for PSBs versus 163 bps for PVBs. (Page 62, Charts IV.11 and IV.12)
Section 89(n) of the scheme defines 'specified date' as the 22nd day of July, 2024. (Page 83)
The industrial sector is estimated to grow by 6.2 per cent in FY25, supported by strong growth in construction and electricity. (Page 56)
